instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
There is a short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> and when I put power into the circuit heat is coming from the area of <CAPACITOR>C2953</CAPACITOR>. I removed all the capacitors on that side of the board and the short is still there so I'm assuming it's coming from <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> on the other side of the board.

Can anyone please give me any info on this chip, like tips on how to remove it, is it replaceable from donor only or can I buy it somewhere, if so part number?

Many thanks in advance for responses.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I don't think I have ever seen <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> die.

At what kind of short are we looking at? What is the resistance to ground in Ohms on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>? How many amps and volts are you injecting?
I assume you have removed all the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> capacitors in that area? (<CAPACITOR>C2950</CAPACITOR>/51/52/53)

If the chip is really what gets hot you should also feel heat on the shield a little

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thanks for the response Smiba. I've been away a few days so sorry for the delay. Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> starts at about 3 ohms and drops steady to about 1 ohm before dropping very slowly. I injected 3.3v and 2a. Yes I removed all caps in that area.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
If you really think its <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>, remove the shield and check its temperature directly at the chip. You can de-solder the shield by pulling it up with your tweezers while heating up the sides where its attached to the board with. I assume its very similar to removing shields on iPhone motherboards, because I have never removed a shield from a macbook

If its indeed getting awfully hot when injecting voltage, remove it and see if the short goes away.
If there is corrosion in that area and the chip does not get very warm you could try a reflow with some nice flux first, you might have corrosion bridging some traces to ground.
If the chip is just at room temperature its most likely not the chip but internally inside the board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Confirmed it's <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>. Short on the actual chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> can be removed of course thunderbolt won't work anymore but it should be able to boot.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Do you have any tips on buying a replacement chip? Are the ones on Ebay generally good? I also need to source a Wifi board connector - is there anywhere I can get that from?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Does the board work without <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>? I wouldn't replace the chip, just live without thunderbolt. WiFi connector needs to come from a donor board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I think you can get the chips from aliexpress or eBay, no idea about the quality though as I never had to replace this chip before. Its densely packed with solder balls so make sure to align it properly
If thunderbolt is no big requirement just go without it as its not worth spending time and money on

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thanks both of you - I appreciate your help.
